title: Stored XSS firing if the error occurs when trying to delete the APM app
vulnerability_information:
Hey team, I have discovered that when the user tries to delete the APM app and some error occurs, the error message contains the app's name, which is not sanitized properly. So the XSS is possible there under certain circumstances. The XSS payload is absolutely simple here, it can be like e.g. ``. The main difficulty is to craft the circumstances when the user tries to delete an app and the error occurs. It means the user *should have the possibility* to delete an app (the gear icon should be visible near the app), but *the deletion process should fails* after victim clicks "delete". When I investigated this, I discovered at least 2 ways to reach this behavior: 1. The first one is when the user opens the apps listing having the rights to delete an app, but before he clicks the "delete" button, his role is changed to "User" and the request fails with 403 after that. 2. The second one is when the user opens the apps listing when the app is disabled (non-active) and before he clicks the "delete" button, the app activates so the APM forbids to delete it. The case #1 is quite difficult to be exploited because the attacker should have at least "admin" role to change the victim's role so he can attack other admins or users and the impact is quite a low in such case. The case #2 is more juicy because it is only needed to create a new app so the **attacker can be simple "user"** here. The case #2 can have an attack scenario like the following: 1. Attacker (user) creates new app with malicious name 2. Attacker craft a malicious page that sends requests to the app to activate it and then redirect the visitor to apps listing page 3. Attacker places the malicious page at the some domain which is looks like real "newrelic.com" 4. Attacker sends the link to malicious page (e.g. `http://nnnewrelic.com/accounts/123/applications`) to admin and asks him to delete the app as if it was accidentally added. 5. Admin clicks the link. Here I used the `prerender` browser directive (``) that force browser to load and render some page in a hidden tab, so the real apps listing is rendered at the background. 6. After the apps listing is loaded (the app is available for deleting still there), the malicious page sends the requests to app so the app becomes active. 7. The victim is redirected to real apps listing (but the prerendered one, so the gear button is still there). 8. Victim (admin) tries to delete an app but the error occurs, and the payload fires. The PoC video demonstrating the scenario above is below: {F464192} The code of malicious page is below: ```html Just a moment...

Checking your browser before accessing newrelic.com.

This process is automatic. Your browser will redirect to your requested content shortly.

Please allow up to 5 seconds...

DDoS protection by CloudFlare
``` The `prerender` directive works at last IE only for now, but I think there can be some other scenarios but I haven't researched it more deeply. So the payload works at every browser, but the most convenient way to attack the user with as few as possible user interactions is to use IE and `prerender` link directive. ###Steps to reproduce It is much easier to demonstrate the vulnerability presence (technically) using admin-to-admin attack, but the real case can be user-to-admin one, as I showed above. 1. Sign into the APM with admin account (victim) 2. Sign into the APM with another admin account (attacker) 3. Set some inactive app's name to `` 4. Navigate to the apps listing as victim 5. Change the victim's role to "User" as attacker 6. Try to delete the malicious app as victim and make sure the XSS alert box is popped up. {F464173} ## Impact Attacker can execute arbitrary JS-code at the victim's browser.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I have discovered that when the user tries to delete the APM app and some error occurs, the error message contains the app's name, which is not sanitized properly. So the XSS is possible there under certain circumstances.

The XSS payload is absolutely simple here, it can be like e.g. <img src=x onerror=alert()>.
The main difficulty is to craft the circumstances when the user tries to delete an app and the error occurs. It means the user should have the possibility to delete an app (the gear icon should be visible near the app), but the deletion process should fails after victim clicks "delete".

When I investigated this, I discovered at least 2 ways to reach this behavior:

  1. The first one is when the user opens the apps listing having the rights to delete an app, but before he clicks the "delete" button, his role is changed to "User" and the request fails with 403 after that.
  2. The second one is when the user opens the apps listing when the app is disabled (non-active) and before he clicks the "delete" button, the app activates so the APM forbids to delete it.

The case #1 is quite difficult to be exploited because the attacker should have at least "admin" role to change the victim's role so he can attack other admins or users and the impact is quite a low in such case.
The case #2 is more juicy because it is only needed to create a new app so the attacker can be simple "user" here.

The case #2 can have an attack scenario like the following:

  1. Attacker (user) creates new app with malicious name
  2. Attacker craft a malicious page that sends requests to the app to activate it and then redirect the visitor to apps listing page
  3. Attacker places the malicious page at the some domain which is looks like real "newrelic.com"
  4. Attacker sends the link to malicious page (e.g. http://nnnewrelic.com/accounts/123/applications) to admin and asks him to delete the app as if it was accidentally added.
  5. Admin clicks the link. Here I used the prerender browser directive (<link rel="prerender" href="https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/2302015/applications">) that force browser to load and render some page in a hidden tab, so the real apps listing is rendered at the background.
  6. After the apps listing is loaded (the app is available for deleting still there), the malicious page sends the requests to app so the app becomes active.
  7. The victim is redirected to real apps listing (but the prerendered one, so the gear button is still there).
  8. Victim (admin) tries to delete an app but the error occurs, and the payload fires.

The PoC video demonstrating the scenario above is below:

The code of malicious page is below:

<html>
<head>
<link rel="prerender" href="https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/2302015/applications">
<title>Just a moment...</title>
<link rel="stylesheet" media="screen" href="/cdn-cgi/styles/js-challenge/error.css" type="text/css">
</head>
<body>
<table width="100%" height="100%" cellpadding="30">
<tr>
<td align="center" valign="center">
<h1>Checking your browser before accessing newrelic.com.</h1>
<noscript>
<h1 style="color:red;"><strong>Please turn JavaScript on and reload the page.</strong></h1>
</noscript>
<div id="challenge">
<p>This process is automatic. Your browser will redirect to your requested content shortly.</p>
<p>Please allow up to 5 seconds...</p>
<img src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/galleriffic/2.0.1/css/loader.gif" style="margin: 40px 0 30px 0;"/>
</div>
<div style="margin-top:20px;">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="font-size: 12px;">DDoS protection by CloudFlare</a>
</div>
<div style="display:none" id="invisible">
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<script>
        function fetchApp() {
                document.getElementById('invisible').innerHTML += '<img src="http://gitlab.bb:8000">';
        }
        setInterval(fetchApp, 500);
        function redirect() {
                window.location.href="https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/2302015/applications";
        }
        setTimeout(redirect, 10000);
</script>
</body>
</html>

The prerender directive works at last IE only for now, but I think there can be some other scenarios but I haven't researched it more deeply. So the payload works at every browser, but the most convenient way to attack the user with as few as possible user interactions is to use IE and prerender link directive.

Steps to reproduce

It is much easier to demonstrate the vulnerability presence (technically) using admin-to-admin attack, but the real case can be user-to-admin one, as I showed above.

  1. Sign into the APM with admin account (victim)
  2. Sign into the APM with another admin account (attacker)
  3. Set some inactive app's name to <img src='x' onerror='alert()'>
  4. Navigate to the apps listing as victim
  5. Change the victim's role to "User" as attacker
  6. Try to delete the malicious app as victim and make sure the XSS alert box is popped up.

Impact

Attacker can execute arbitrary JS-code at the victim's browser.

activities.message: Hahaha, nice find @skavans . I'll work on trying to reproduce this today. That's certainly a very clever way to trigger an XSS. I could learn a thing or two from you :)
activities.markdown_message: Hahaha, nice find @skavans . I'll work on trying to reproduce this today. That's certainly a very clever way to trigger an XSS. I could learn a thing or two from you :)

activities.message:
Once again, an excellent find @skavans !

Because the execution of this vulnerability is significantly more difficult, we feel like the likelihood merits downgrading this to a Medium severity. 

We'll get right to working on this, and will reach out once this is resolved.

Thanks again for helping to keep NR safe!
activities.markdown_message:
Once again, an excellent find @skavans !

Because the execution of this vulnerability is significantly more difficult, we feel like the likelihood merits downgrading this to a Medium severity.

We'll get right to working on this, and will reach out once this is resolved.

Thanks again for helping to keep NR safe!

activities.message:
Hey guys,

I have discovered a way to decrease the difficulty of firing the payload. Is it interesting to you? Will you increase the impact and so a payload amount if I describe this way? Or you do not pay more after the issue is triaged? Thanks for reply :)
activities.markdown_message:
Hey guys,

I have discovered a way to decrease the difficulty of firing the payload. Is it interesting to you? Will you increase the impact and so a payload amount if I describe this way? Or you do not pay more after the issue is triaged? Thanks for reply :)

activities.message: The way I have found uses the same error message but for another objects – the app labels. So this is how to plant the payload: 1) Navigate to APM apps listing 2) Click `Show labels` 3) Add some label to some app and intercept the request 4) Change the `label_key` parameter value to `:asdasd` 5) Update the page, click `Show labels` again and try to delete the malicious label. The payload will fire. {F466306} So the execution of payload becomes much easier and the victim just should try to delete the malicious label.
activities.markdown_message:
The way I have found uses the same error message but for another objects – the app labels. So this is how to plant the payload:
1) Navigate to APM apps listing
2) Click Show labels
3) Add some label to some app and intercept the request
4) Change the label_key parameter value to <img src=x onerror='alert()'>:asdasd
5) Update the page, click Show labels again and try to delete the malicious label. The payload will fire.

So the execution of payload becomes much easier and the victim just should try to delete the malicious label.

activities.message:
Hey @dday,
What's about my last message?
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @dday,
What's about my last message?

activities.message:
Hey @skavans ,

Thanks for providing the additional info! Given the fact that you'd still have to social engineer someone into deleting your label, we're going to leave this as a Medium. But I'm looking forward to more awesome bugs by you :) Our team has been laughing at how cool your XSS bugs are!
